title: Wednesday, 6th December, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:03am

Morning! Welcome to Markets Live, where we have all the news. All at once.

BE11:03am

BE11:03am

Spin down to paragraph four.

11:03 am
BE11:04am

M&A to the rescue? We think not

BE11:04am

Uh, oh.

BE11:04am

Hammerson is the most obvious acquirer for Intu, however the strategic fit is far from perfect given Hammerson’s deliberate move away from the UK in recent years. [...] A combination [with Intu] would compromise Hammerson’s balance sheet, hijack the strategy and FFO accretion relies almost entirely on refinancing synergies. This does not make a compelling case for a merger."

11:04 am
BE11:04am

That's what he published at 6.18am.

BE11:04am

And then, 42 minutes later ....

BE11:04am

11:04 am
BE11:04am

That's .............. well, that's just bad luck really.

BE11:05am

The Intu-Hammerson deal had been rumoured for approximately five years and makes sense right now only on one level, as in: it's cheap.

BE11:06am

It's still a terrible deal! But, it's cheap. Much like Regal-Cineworld, it's M&A that makes sense only for the EPS bump.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

But just to quickly recap detail, Hammerson is buying Intu.

BE11:06am

You can call it a merger if you want. You can, if you're a shareholder of either company, call it a stitch-up. Because it certainly looks like one.

BE11:07am

I'd also assume going to be played in some parts of the press as John Whittaker being canny.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

The other intepretation here is that he built an overly indebted and underinvested shambles of assets, mostly stuck in the wrong places, and is now having to swap it for a rival's equity because the possibility of Intu needing a rescue rights issue was growing ever larger. Is that canny? I'm not entirely sure that's canny.

BE11:07am

But we're getting ahead of ourselves.

BE11:08am

The new business will be called ..... Hammerson.

11:07 am
BE11:08am

Hammerson CEO David Atkins will be CEO, Hammerson CFO Timon Drakesmith will CFO.

BE11:08am

John Whittaker, who of course is deputy chairman of Intu, will become deputy chairman of Hammerson.

BE11:08am

And Hammerson shareholders -- including, uncomfortably, John Whittaker! Since he bought up nearly 5% earlier this year -- end up owning approximately 55% of the enlarged group.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

0.475 new Hammerson shares for each Intu share.

BE11:09am

Which was 534.5p at the start of trade, but now isn't.

Hammerson PLC (HMSO:LSE): Last: 527.00, down 7.5 (-1.40%), High: 528.00, Low: 507.00, Volume: 6.97m
11:08 am
Intu Properties PLC (INTU:LSE): Last: 239.10, up 40.1 (+20.15%), High: 242.00, Low: 228.40, Volume: 22.17m
BE11:09am

And is also a 50% discount to the trailing NAV

BE11:09am

And, really, it looks pretty much done. Support of the INTU board and 50.6% of INTU shareholdersm, which of course includes Whittaker's Peel Holdings with 27.2%.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Here's the simple take, from Kempen.

BE11:10am

We believe the deal is rather opportunistic and well timed by Hammerson, as it is rare to be able to take advantage of such a large NAV discount. Added to this HMSO have indicated their desire for expanding on the continent, and we believe the Spanish pipeline is something that could have enticed them.

BE11:10am

Okay, but back to the price.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

The Intu price has been flagging for some time was that a cash call was a high possibility.

BE11:12am

We noted here and elsewhere about investment needs for Spain, where management just did a tour of the Xanadu centre and there's a big Costa Del Mall getting built for the middle of next decade.

BE11:12am

Spin forward, and today's statement flags £25m annual savings by the end of the second year, equivalent to 13% of Intu earnings, against a one-off integration cost of £40m.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

(And incidentally, you have to wonder how much of those savings are just wage costs after the sacking of the Intu board, who I'm sure are cock-a-hoop this morning.)

BE11:13am

So. Against the inherited 50% NAV discount Hammerson gets only £25m of earnings uplift that gets dumped by £40m one-off costs and a disposal programme of at least £2bn.

BE11:13am

As in, most likely getting shot of the weakest stuff UK in Intu's portfolio. What kind of NAV discounts will that require? Who are the buyers?

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Judith Evans did a good writethrough on the sector in October, which notes the big hit LandSec had to take on Bluewater: https://www.ft.com...-8cd4-932067fbf946

BE11:13am

All of which makes it an utter nonsense to say it's earnings accretive in the first year.

BE11:13am

Note also the rather lazy schedule. Prospectus and scheme document not due until end April 2018. Completion is for Q4 2018.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Jefferies' Mike Prew, the most readable of the real estate bears, ain't impressed.

BE11:14am

This highlights that no matter how prime a REIT claims its assets to be, much depends on its capital stack and that means the level of gearing as well as its structure. Once the 42.5% sale of the stake in Bluewater prints (LAND has already marked its share down by -5% along with the St David’s Centre in Cardiff) probably in 1H18, we believe the shopping centre market is likely to crack in valuation terms with this subordinated stake with an evergreen management agreement with LAND. That’s worse news for INTU than HMSO due to INTU’s bond structure which is a yoke around the INTU managements neck as gearing creeps above 50% (June 47%) the business is restricted in assets transfers in an out of the security pool and its ability to deploy development cap ex, the lifeblood of any real estate business. Lower gearing is HMSO's leverage in this transaction and HMSO will comprise 55% of the merged entity, its board will run the combined group and gets naming rights. INTU’s 47% gearing is excessive (vs HMSOs 1H17 40%) and HMSO's estimate merged gearing ratio is 41% and we would assume HMSOs 4.8% DY on the enlarged group. The disappointing aspects are no cash alternative and the year to completion with likely significant anti-trust hurdles to overcome.

BE11:14am

How does this leave the sector? This is not a cash bid for a high-quality UK REIT by an overseas buyer which would trigger a re-rating of the sector but a coalition of weak business models with 25% INTU shareholder Peel Holdings preferring to take its chances with HMSO management (and diluted front to 15% of the enlarged group) and greater liquidity in the shares.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

And Goodbody, who ain't impressed.

BE11:15am

We liked the growing non-UK exposure of HMSO, particularly given the broad uncertainty in the UK property market. In terms of asset mix, HMSO is c.50%/50% UK/Europe but INTU is c.90% UK biased. As such the pro forma assets mix is c.70%/30% UK/Europe, a figure that is still 66/67% post the proposed UK disposals. Indeed, the combined entity is looking to reinvest these proceeds in Ireland, Spain and the Premium Outlets which may see the UK share of assets drift further downward in time.

BE11:16am

We focused our view on HMSO recently on two key theses; growing non-UK exposure and focus on best-in-class quality UK assets. This message is not consistent with the offer today with the enlarged entity created a UK centric entity (c.67% combined vs. c.50% for HMSO). Furthermore, the addition of lower grade assets from INTU dilutes the quality offering. However, heavy discounting (offer implies a 37% discount for INTU) allows headroom for value falls, but with HSMO at a 31% discount, we query if the spread is enough to reflect the differences.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Course, it seems highly unlikely that we'll be hearing from John Whittaker himself.

BE11:17am

Whose last public interview was, I believe, in 2011.

BE11:17am

And is here: https://www.ft.com...-9b3b-00144feabdc0

11:18 am
BE11:19am

If anyone has a photo of the Trafford Centre's "bronze busts [of CSC management] above a Romanesque monument of frolicking dolphins" mentioned in the story, I'd very much like to see that.

BE11:20am

My person close to the Trafford Centre tells me he used to have offices there in a dome on site, a bit like a Bond villain.

BE11:21am

Anyway, let me see if there's any more sellside to chuck up here.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

...... Stifel.

BE11:23am

A takeover offer for Intu does not come as a surprise to us give the consistent under- performance of the shares and the market’s apparent lack of confidence in the company (Intu’s shares were trading at a 51% discount to current NAV yesterday vs Hammerson at 32%). We think the market will welcome an enlarged REIT, which will sit alongside Land Securities in market cap, and will be more meaningful from a global perspective for REIT investors. However, the structural difficulties for Retail property remain, although we believe the combined entity will be better placed to manage these headwinds with a more proactive management team.

BE11:24am

And Citi.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

Actually, nah, Citi's boring. As is Goldman.

BE11:25am

And nothing yet from Morgan Stanley, which will probably get some attention for doing a fantasy M&A note on this possibility over the summer.

BE11:26am

Spin back in the archive for details of that.

The idea when they bought Poundland was that it was the start of a giant cross-border rollup thing. Kinda doesn't look that way now.

BE11:37am

The company last updated the market in late October when it released a trading update that outlined an in-line
trading performance since the start of the financial year and trading patterns have been similar to those
outlined in September s AGM update. This year's inflationary paper price environment has created a headwind
to profitability for DS Smith and while it seeks to recover higher input costs, guidance is for the RoS in H1 2018
to be in line with FY2017, implying some margin contraction compared with H1 2017. With no obvious material
negative impact on returns, ROACE is expected to be at the upper end of management 12-15% target range.
Further, October update described the performance of the Interstate Resources acquisition as strong, its
integration was proceeding well and management remained confident on its prospects. The completion of the
acquisition of EcoPack & EcoPaper remains on track to complete during Q3 of this fiscal year. A summary of
our financial expectations for H1 2018 includes: reported revenues of £2,599m (+10.3% yoy), EBITA of £241m
(+6.6% yoy), equating to an EBITA margin of 9.3% (H1 2017: 9.6%). Our forecast for adj. PBT for H1 2018 is
£214m. We believe the greatest risks of upside surprises are in faster than expected volume growth and the
impact of acquisitions on the financial performance during the current financial year. Ahead of the release of
interims, we retain our 530p target price and HOLD recommendation.

BE11:38am

And Davy.

DS Smith has been active on the M&A front again this year with the acquisition of Interstate Resources in the US and EcoPaper in Romania. More recently, the company has been linked with plastics packaging company Bemis, as well as a large European packaging company. The acquisitions completed this year contribute to our forecast of 17% growth in FY 2018 EBITDA and a further 11% in FY 2019. With implied net debt/EBITDA now exceeding the company’s target of 2x, any future acquisition activity will have to rely on the further support of shareholders.

BE11:44am

The company released unexpected trading update today on the trading outlook for year-ending 31/1/2018 and 31/1/2019.

For the year-ending 31/1/2018, the company expects underlying PBT to be 1-2% ahead of 2017 (£187.4m). This suggests underlying PBT of £190m and 3% downgrade vs consensus (£196m) and 6% vs. our estimate (£200.9m).

This is due to more challenging trading environment in home and travel insurance broking and Monarch Airlines administration (one off cost of £2m in the tour operations business). This is offset by positive claims environment and the company has now guided that reserve releases should be at similar level to last year £63m (RBCe: £53m). There will also be £4m below the line restructuring charge, which the company expects will lead to £10m cost savings in future years.

For the year ended 31/1/2019, the company expects underlying PBT to be 5% lower than current year i.e. c.£180m. This is 17% downgrade to consensus (c.£210m) and 18% downgrade to our estimate (£213.6m). This is due to £10m additional customer acquisition spend, written to earned adjustment, offset by £10m cost savings from restructuring activity from the previous year.

The trading update is clearly negative for the company in the short-term, but we believe that the additional customer acquisition spend for targeted marketing will be positive for the future growth of the company to capture new business. Commentary for the motor broking business is positive as the company is seeing ‘strong performance’ in this area and this provides a silver lining.

Yep. There's been talk around in recent days about Japan changing taxation of those silly cigarette warmer coffin things.

BE11:54am

Which are an obsession for the industry, because neither Imps not JT have much in the way of heat-not-burn product and Japan's the only market where they've really caught on.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Which we can blame on social anthropology as much as anything.

BE11:55am

Anyway, here's Jefferies to talk through the detail.

BE11:55am

Headlines overnight that the Japanese government plan to raise tax on heated tobacco to 80% of the tax levied on cigarettes over five stages beginning October 2018. Japan makes up c.40% of Japan Tobacco (2914 JP, U/P) EBIT, c.6% at Philip Morris (PM, Hold) and c.2% at British American (BATS LN, Buy).

11:55 am
BE11:56am

Tax in Japan on heated tobacco is currently assigned on a weight basis. As a result, its estimated IQOS (PM) attracts tax around 80% that of cigarettes already, Glo (BAT) at c.60% that of cigarettes, and Ploom Tech (JT) at c.15% that of cigarettes. Based on these current estimated tax levies, we believe the rumoured proposals are a big negative for JT, a slight negative for BAT and a positive for PM.

BE11:56am

And on the broader view ....

BE11:57am

We still see taxes moving to parity globally over the long term: Taxes across reduced risk (heated and vapour) currently vary greatly, with some markets not having any tax (other than a sales tax), while in markets where there is a tax it can range between 15%-80%. How the tax structure evolves will have a big impact on future growth rates. In our recent scenario analysis as per our 'new tobacco model' note here, in a situation where long-term taxes remain 50% that of cigarettes globally we see long-term global sector organic sales growth averaging c.6% (with the assumed leaders BAT and PM averaging over 7%). We think such an outcome is unlikely, however, with tax parity to cigarettes over the long-term the most likely outcome. While observers may point to these Japan proposals as evidence of a potentially more favourable long-term approach to reduced risk we would urge caution around modelling this out into the future (and would not be surprised if the 80% moves higher in future budgets as the category continues to grow). Our current base case estimates, where we assume long-term tax parity with cigarettes globally, implies long-term global sector organic sales growth of c.4% (with the assumed leaders BAT and PM averaging c.5%). Approaches taken by other markets/regions over the next 12 months will be a key watch-out for how the tax environment could evolve (and how growth is modelled). Particularly important will be the US (where we understand heated tobacco will be treated like cigarettes but favourable treatment currently persists in vapour) and the EU (a legislative proposal for how it plans to tax reduced risk is expected very soon).

Actually, on Steinhoff, Credit Suisse have said "nah, out, not doing this any more".

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Until such time as there is clarity over the legal cases, which rest on the beneficial ownership of two of its largest subsidiaries Conforama and Poco, and the nature of the accounting irregularities, we believe it is not possible to value Steinhoff, hence we move our rating to “Not Rated” until sufficient clarity emerges to enable an investment opinion.

BE12:01pm

Holy hell look at the leverage in this thing.

BE12:01pm

We have previously forecast Y/E Sept 17 net debt of EUR5bn; however, pensions and prefs at Sept 2016 were €794m and cash and equivalents €3.8bn, so gross debt could be c€9.6bn. Moreover lease liabilities at the last year end were €15bn. If Steinhoff were a forced seller of assets, much of its portfolio is relatively unattractive in our view and separating the Household Goods retail from manufacturing would be complex. We regard apparel retailer Pepkor, with 2016 EBIT of €362m to be the only large attractive asset, as well as the property portfolio.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

The principal legal issue is probably the cases concerning the acquisitions of Poco in 2008 and Conforama in 2011 with Andreas Seifert, and the related issue of false accounting in Netherlands where the court is due to rule by Dec 22nd. This could result in Steinhoff not having had 100% ownership of these assets since acquisition and with 2016 EBIT of c€110m and €186m respectively an adverse ruling would have material implications.

BE12:02pm

Remember when Steinhoff tried to buy Argos? And Darty?

BE12:03pm

And remember when Elliott successfully managed to bump them on Poundland by lying down in front of the steamroller?

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Ended up paying 227p a share, a 43% premium. For Poundland.

undefined
BE12:04pm

Update! From Michael Burt at Exane.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Which is of course where we started.

BE12:04pm

Well, we were wrong about that

BE12:04pm

Thumbs up

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

His argument remains much the same.

BE12:05pm

The merger goes against Hammerson’s strategy of diversifying the portfolio away from the UK in recent years. The combination also compromises Hammerson’s balance sheet by increasing LTV to 41% on a pro forma basis (44% if the company wants to refinance Intu’s debt in full). Earnings accretion relies heavily on refinancing and Intu will dilute the total return outlook for the combined group.

BE12:06pm

Talk also that Hammerson "may require more substantial disposals" than the £2bn flagged. I'm still struggling to identify buyers here, unless someone can figure out how to convert big empty shopping centres into housing.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

On the surface, Hammerson is acquiring Intu at a 2019e P/FFO multiple of 16.0x by issuing shares at 15.5x. This is before adjusting Intu’s earnings for c.GBP 25m p.a. of legacy swap interest costs through the cashflow. On this cash basis, Intu is being acquired at 18.0x P/ FFO making the deal earnings dilutive pre-synergies. A lot rests on NPV neutral refinancing activity.

BE12:07pm

So, that's that.
